Chapter 2.50

Summer 1438, Late Afternoon

The doors of the council chamber have barely closed behind Ser Francesco Tornabuoni. Through the open windows, the late afternoon light stretches across the Tagus valley, gilding the rocky escarpments and the ancient bridges far below. The heat of the day has begun to break, and somewhere in the city, church bells mark the hour of vespers.

Don Álvaro de Luna stands by the window, watching the Medici factor's small retinue make its way down from the Alcázar toward the Toledo streets. When he turns back to you, there is something rare in his expression—a kind of bemused admiration that he makes no effort to hide.

"In thirty years of serving the crown of Castile," he says quietly, "I have seen many negotiations. I have never seen a banker's hands tremble before." He moves to the wine table, pours two cups, and offers you one. "You understand what you have proposed? Not merely a business arrangement—you have offered to make the House of Medici's survival dependent upon your continued favor. Cosimo will either embrace this as salvation or view it as a snare. There will be no middle ground."

He drinks, then sets down his cup. "We have covered much today. The silver, the mint, the arts, the bank. Is there more you wish to address this evening, or shall we let the letters travel and the plans unfold?"

Its funny Alvaro how sometimes things come together. I knew that I just wanted the mint to be set up but I was still unsure about what they would be minting. And the Florentines will help me spread it. Still need to come up with the symbol of my empire... Basileus has Xe-Ro. I will require...something else. It will come to me.

Álvaro raises an eyebrow, swirling the wine in his cup as he considers your words.

"Florins," he repeats, letting the word hang in the air. "You mean to take the very name of Florence's coin and make it your own. Cosimo will appreciate the... boldness of that. Or perhaps not." A dry smile crosses his weathered face. "Though I suppose if he becomes dependent upon your favor, his appreciation matters less than it once did."

He moves to one of the high-backed chairs and settles into it, the ease of long familiarity with these chambers evident in every motion.

"The Chi-Rho serves Constantinople because it is ancient—older than the Empire itself, the very monogram of Christ. It claims continuity with Constantine, with the faith itself." He taps his fingers against the arm of the chair, thinking. "Your symbol must do different work. You are not continuing an old empire. You are building something new from many crowns—Castile, León, Aragon, Naples, and whatever titles Constantinople may yet yield. The symbol must bind them without subsuming them."

He pauses, studying you with that shrewd gaze that has guided Castilian policy for two decades.

"The great houses of Europe use their arms. The Church uses the keys of Peter. What image, Majestad, do you wish men to see when they hold your coin in their hands? What thought should enter their minds?"

The house sits in the gentle hills outside Toledo, far enough from the Alcázar that the children can run and shout without the weight of ceremony pressing down upon them. You find them in the garden, where the summer light has turned golden and long shadows stretch across the grass.

Fernando—nearly five now, with that magnificent frame that promises the warrior's build he will never truly inhabit—is organizing the younger children into some elaborate game involving sticks and imaginary castles. Scooping up the squirming toddler with practiced ease, she continues: "The Medici do not keep all their deposits in vaults, you know. They lend them out. She trails off, studying your face. Lucia has always been quick.

"You were not actually going to withdraw it. You wanted him to think you might." She settles Teresa on her hip, the child's protests fading into tired whimpers. "What were you after? Better terms? Information? Or just to see what a frightened Florentine looks like?"

In the garden behind her, the wooden horse dispute has resolved itself—Bianca has claimed victory and is now galloping the toy across the grass while making horse noises. Fernando has diplomatically redirected the dispossessed Teresa's attention toward a beetle crawling along the stone path.

Diego de Daza's expression shifts as he reads the dispatch that a clerk has just brought in—the latest from the Andalusian ports where news from Morocco filters through fishing boats and merchant vessels.

"Majestad..." He sets down the paper, and you recognize that particular tone. The one that means the news is not good. "This arrived three days ago from Cádiz. A Genoese merchant who trades in Tétouan."

He reads aloud:

"The Christian traders have vanished from the souk. The one called Martín and his companions—gone since before the spring rains. The governor's men came asking questions. Someone talked. A tanner, I think. They took him away and he did not return. The others disappeared that same night. No one speaks of them now. It is as if they were never there."

Daza sets down the dispatch. "There's more. A second report, from a fisherman who puts in at Tangier. He says the mood has turned cold toward anyone with Castilian connections. The local authorities are watching the ports more carefully. And Commander Martín's trade house—the leather goods shop that served as their cover—has been shuttered. The neighbors say the owners 'returned to al-Andalus.'"

He spreads his hands. "No direct communication from Commander Martín in four months, Majestad. If he and Fernando are alive—and I believe they are, or we would have heard of executions—they have gone to ground. Deep cover. It may be a year before they can safely re-establish contact."

The morning light falls across the table, illuminating five years of reports that now read like a chronicle of patient effort brought to nothing.

"The network is not destroyed," Daza says carefully. "But it is dark. And whatever contacts they built... those relationships will need to be rebuilt from the beginning. Trust, once broken in that world, does not easily mend."

Daza's eyebrows rise as he reads the report from Governor Padilla's agents.

"Well. This is... unexpected." He passes you the document. "The Banu Rashid. I know the name—they control much of the silk trade between Granada and the Italian merchants. Prosperous. Respected, even among Christians. I had no idea of their history."

He summarizes what the report contains:

The Banu Rashid were lords in the region around Tétouan three generations ago—not the city itself, but productive lands in the hills above it. Orchards, pastures, a small but profitable domain. Then the al-Mandri clan rose to power, and in the violent reshuffling that followed, the Rashid patriarch was killed, his sons scattered, and the family's lands seized.

The survivors fled to Granada, where they rebuilt as merchants. They have done well—very well. The current patriarch, Ahmad al-Rashid, is past seventy now, but his mind remains sharp. He has four sons: the eldest, Khalid, manages the family's trading house; the second, Tariq, has a reputation as a man who solves problems that require discretion; the third, Yusuf, is scholarly and pious; the youngest, Omar, is barely twenty and hungry to prove himself.

"They approached Governor Padilla's people indirectly," Daza explains. "Through a Christian merchant who owes them money. Very careful. Very deniable. But the message was clear enough."

He reads from the report:

"The old man says his family has waited three generations for justice. He does not expect to live to see Tétouan again—but his grandsons might. If the King of Castile looks south, the Banu Rashid remember their lands. They remember who took them. And they remember that enemies of enemies may find common purpose."

Daza sets down the paper. "They are not offering to convert, Majestad. They would remain Muslim—Muslim lords ruling Muslim subjects under Christian suzerainty. The Church will have opinions about that. So will the Moroccans, though different ones." He pauses. "But they have something Commander Martín's network never had: a claim. Legitimate grievance. Blood debt. The people of that region may remember the Banu Rashid. Some may even welcome them back, if the alternative is the al-Mandri."

He folds his hands. "Governor Padilla asks for guidance. Do you wish to meet with them? And if so... openly, or in the shadows?"
